attributes.title: “Where is the sticker now?” A Set Shifting task for 3-5-year olds with minimal verbal demands.

q1.value: “Where is the sticker now?” A Set Shifting task for 3-5-year olds with minimal verbal demands.

q2.value: Eva Reindl, Amanda Seed, Jessica Campbell-May

q3.value:
Attentional set shifting represents one of the core executive functions (EFs), describing the ability to flexibly switch attention between rules or mental “sets”. It allows an individual to quickly and flexibly adapt to new demands, problems or rules. The preschool years are a crucial period in the development of EFs. As EFs are crucial for regulating other cognitive abilities such as reading and writing and are predictive of school readiness, professional success later in life, and health behaviours, assessing EF abilities in preschool years has gained significant research interest. 
However, to date, there is still a shortage of tasks assessing attentional set shifting in pre-schoolers. The most prominent task is the Dimensional Change Card Sort Test (DCCCS). However, this task has been criticized for posing a substantial language demand on children; in addition, cross-cultural research has shown that the task also requires experience with culture-specific arbitrary symbol-response mappings.
Therefore, based on existing “two-choice complex stimulus discrimination” set shifting tasks (such as the Intradimensional/Extradimensional (ID/ED) task of the Cambridge Neuropsychological Automated Test Battery (CANTAB), we have created a new, non-verbal set shifting task (Shifting Tray task) without the need for prior experience with abstract, symbolic print materials. As the DCCS, the task consists of a pre- and a post-switch phase. 
The study will investigate 1) the feasibility of the task for children between 3 and 5 years of age, 2) whether we can replicate the finding that extradimensional shifts are more difficult that intradimensional shifts (as they require a shift between two dimensions), 3) whether there is an increase in task performance with age and 4) whether potential prepotent biases towards stimulus dimensions facilitate/exacerbate shifting performance.

q4.value:
Preswitch phase:
H1 - directed: Age: Older children need fewer number of trials to reach the learning criterion in the preswitch phase than younger children

H2 – directed: Relevant dimension in preswitch: children in conditions in which one of the cups is predictive of the reward will need fewer trials to reach the learning criterion than children for whom one of the substrates is relevant

H3 – not directed: interaction between Age and relevant dimension in preswitch: one might assume that the effect of the relevant dimension in preswitch (i.e., that “cup” is easier than “substrate”) will only be found in older children, as older children have more experience with cups and their function as containers and thus might be more biased towards assuming that the relevant dimension is one of the cups. In contrast, younger children, who lack that experience, would need a comparable number of trials to reach the learning criterion for cup and substrate, respectively. However, one could also assume the opposite relationship, in that the effect of the relevant dimension in preswitch is only found in young children: This line of thinking would assume that both older and younger children have substantial experience with cups as containers and thus would be biased in assuming that one of the cups is predictive of the reward. Crucially, however, younger children would struggle more to overcome this prepotent bias, whereas older children could learn more quickly from the negative feedback.

Postswitch phase:
H4 – directed: interaction between Age and switch type: There will be an effect of switch type, i.e., that children in the IDS condition need fewer trials to reach the learning criterion than children in the EDS condition, which is dependent on age: the effect of switch type will be most pronounced at the age of 4, whereas at the age of 3, the effect will be smaller as children will find both conditions comparably difficult. At the age of 5, the effect will also be smaller as children will find both conditions comparable easy.

If we fail to find an interaction, we predict the presence of two main effects:
H4a – directed: Age: older children need fewer number of trials to reach the learning criterion in the postswitch phase than younger children

H4b – directed: Switch type: children in the IDS conditions will need fewer trials to reach the learning criterion in the postswitch phase than children in the EDS conditions

Further hypotheses:
H5 – directed: Relevant dimension in postswitch: children for whom one of the cups is relevant will need fewer trials to reach the criterion than children for whom a substrate is relevant.

H6 – not directed: three-way interaction between age, relevant dimension in postswitch and switch type. We will also test for a possible three-way interaction to see whether the effect of relevant dimension in postswitch differs depending on switch type and age. However, we do not have any expectation about the nature of such a relationship.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The Tray Task is based on a two-choice complex stimulus discrimination learning procedure. In each trial, children will be presented with two transparent square plastic trays (20.3 x 20.3 x 5.1 cm) placed next to each other. The trays differ on two dimensions: each tray is filled with a different substrate, and each tray has a different cup placed upside down on top of the substrate in the middle of the tray (see Fig. 1 for an example). Over the course of the trials (see below), each combination of materials and location of the trays (left/right) is counterbalanced.
There are 2 sets of materials:
-	Set 1: 
        Cups: yellow, purple 
        Substrates: red paper, green sand
-	Set 2:
        Cups: orange, pink
        Substrates: yellow Easter basket filling material, blue cotton wool

Children will be asked to look for a sticker. In each trial, they can only choose one tray to search (forced choice paradigm). Out of children’s sight (i.e., behind an occluder), the experimenter hides a sticker on one of the trays, underneath one of the cups. Depending on the condition (see below), it is either one of the cups or one of the substrates which is predictive of the reward. The same stimulus will be predictive of the reward until the end of the preswitch phase is reached (i.e., when the learning criterion or the maximum number of trials is reached). If, and only if, a child reaches the learning criterion, they proceed to the postswitch phase. In the postswitch phase, all materials change (total change paradigm; from set 1 to set 2 or vice versa). Depending on the condition, the dimension predictive of the stimulus will either be the same as in the preswitch phase (Intradimensional (ID) switch) or the dimension that was irrelevant in the preswitch phase (Extradimensional (ED) switch).

We have a between-subjects 3 x 2 x 2 multifactorial design (age: 3 years, 4 years, 5 years; switch type: ID/ED; start dimension: cup/substrate) design with random allocation to condition within each age group, resulting in four conditions per age group (ID-cup, ID-substrate, ED-cup, ED-substrate), see Table 1.

The maximum number of trials in both the preswitch and postswitch phases is 36, respectively. Trials are grouped into 3 blocks of 12 in order to facilitate counterbalancing. 
Counterbalancing is used according to material positions and combinations and location of the sticker. As a result, in each block of 12 trials, each stimulus and stimulus combination will occur equally often on both the left and the right tray (e.g., the red paper will occur 6 times on the left tray (3 times with the yellow container, 3 times with the purple tumbler) and 6 times on the right tray (again 3 times with the yellow container, 3 times with the purple tumbler). In addition, we use the rule that the same stimulus cannot appear more than three times in a row on the same location.

Gender will also be counterbalanced throughout study implementation. 

Participants first take part in the preswitch phase. This ends when the participant has reached the learning criterion (6 trials in a row correct in block 1 or – if children do not reach this criterion and move on to the next block, any 9 out of 12 trials in either block 2 or 3 correct) or when the maximum number of 36 trials is reached.
If, and only if, the learning criterion is met, children proceed to the postswitch phase. Here, all materials will be exchanged (total change paradigm). Depending on the condition, children then experience either an ID switch (from cup to cup or from substrate to substrate) or an ED switch (from cup to substrate or from substrate to cup). This switch is not being announced to the child. The postswitch phase ends when the learning criterion is met (same as in preswitch) or the maximum number of trials (36) is reached.

For a more exploratory analysis, participants will be asked after completion of the task to articulate how they found the sticker in the postswitch phase.

q9.value: We use a blocked randomisation, where each participant will first be assigned to one of three age blocks (3, 4, 5 years). Then, within each block, participants are first randomly assigned to one of the four conditions (ID-cup, ID-substrate, ED-cup, ED-substrate). Throughout the study, a counterbalancing sheet will be used to keep track of the numbers of participants as well as their gender in each condition. Based on this, new participants will be assigned to the conditions in a way that ensures that each condition has a comparable number of participants and that gender is also spread equally across conditions.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: Registration prior to completion of data collection: Data collection is under way, but the existing data have not been digitalised yet.

question.value:
Data will be collected at the Science Centre in Dundee through voluntary sampling. A paper advertisement will be displayed requesting participants between the ages of 3 years and 5 years and 11 months to take part in research taking approximately 25 minutes. All participants between these ages can be included, there are no exclusion criteria other than age. Families interested in taking part in the research will be given more information about the study (orally as well as in the form of an information sheet) and given the opportunity to ask questions. If the family decides to take part, the guardian of the participating child will give written informed consent. Families will be debriefed after the study (orally and with a debrief form) and given the opportunity to ask questions.

Data is intended to be collected across 5-10 visits to the Science Centre which may be amended according to success rates and ease of recruitment. Efforts will be made to collect data on weekends and throughout school holidays to maximise participant numbers.

q13.value:
Our target final sample size is 108. We will probably test more children in order to make up for dropouts. 
There will be 36 slots in each age category (3 years to 3 years 11 months, 4 years to 4 years 11 months and 5 years to 5 years 11 months, where age is rounded down to the nearest month). For each age, 18 children will experience an intra-dimensional shift, whilst 18 will experience an extradimensional shift. 9 of each of these groups will have one of the cups baited first, with the other 9 having one of the substrates baited. Within each 9, for 5 children material set 1 (yellow cup, purple cup, red paper, green sand) will be the start set, and for the remaining 4 children it will be set 2 (pink cup, orange cup, yellow filling material, blue wool). Therefore, there is a ratio of 5:4 according to which combinations of materials are used first. For each set, there are 5 different coding sheets that differ in trial order. For each sheet, trials were grouped into 3 blocks of 12 trials; within each block, trials were arranged in a pseudo-random fashion so that the location and combination of the stimuli were counterbalanced, with no more than 3 of the same cup or material on the same side in a row.

q14.value: The target sample size reflects the maximum number possible given the time and workload constraints associated with this student project.

q15.value: Data collection will cease when the final sample size of 108 is hit, or otherwise at the end of February 2020 due to time restrictions on this student project.

question.value:
Preswitch predictive dimension: The two levels of this factor are cup and substrate. Each child starts either with one of the cups being predictive of the reward or with one of the substrates.

Start set: The two levels of the variable are set 1 (purple cup, yellow cup, red paper, green sand) and set 2 (orange cup, pink cup, blue cotton, yellow filling material).

Predictive stimulus in preswitch phase: Within each dimension and set, it is either cup 1 or cup 2 (and substrate 1 and substrate 2, respectively) which are predictive of the reward in the preswitch phase. Within each dimension and set, the variable has 2 levels.

Switch type: We manipulate switch type as a between-subjects factor. The two levels of the variable are intradimensional switch (i.e., cup to cup, or material to material) or extradimensional switch (i.e., cup to material or material to cup).

•	Age: For the analysis, for each participant age will be measured as a continuous variable (age in months).
•	Completed preswitch phase (i.e., either reached criterion or maximum number of trials): yes/no 
•	Number of administered trials in preswitch (possible numbers 12, 24, 36)
•	Preswitch criterion reached: yes/no
•	If criterion reached, number of trial after which criterion was reached in preswitch (possible range 6-12 or 21-36)
•	Preswitch number of errors
•	On a trial by trial basis: Success_Preswitch (i.e., was sticker found; yes/no)

•	Started postswitch phase: yes/no
•	Completed postswitch phase (i.e., either reached criterion or maximum number of trials; yes/no) 
•	Number of administered trials in postswitch (possible numbers 12, 24, 36)
•	Postswitch criterion reached: yes/no
•	If criterion reached, number of trial after which criterion was reached in postswitch (possible range 6-12 or 21-36)
•	Postswitch number of errors
•	On a trial by trial basis: Success_Postswitch (i.e., was sticker found; yes/no)

We will use General Linear Mixed Models with binomial outcome variables to analyse our data. We will enter age in months as a covariate into all models. 

Preswitch:
Data will be sorted into the long format (one line per trial). For the preswitch analysis, the DV will be Success_Preswitch, i.e., whether or not the child found the sticker in each trial. We will use age as a covariate, relevant dimension in the preswitch phase (cup/substrate) as the independent variable, as well as the interaction between age and relevant dimension. Trial number will also be included as a fixed effect. Participant ID will be included as a random effect. If the interaction term turns out to not be significant, we remove it and re-run the model with age, relevant dimension, and trial number only and will test for any main effects.

Success_Preswitch = age*relevant dimension in preswitch (cup/substrate) + trial number + (1|ID)

We will also run this analysis separately for children in the IDS and EDS conditions in order to check for the absence of any cohort effects. That is, we would expect to find an effect of relevant dimension (or its absence) for children in both the IDS and the EDS condition, thereby showing that children of these two conditions did not differ in any meaningful way other than switch type.


Postswitch:
For the postswitch analysis, we will use age as a covariate, relevant dimension in the postswitch phase (cup/substrate) and switch type (IDS/EDS) as independent variables, as well as a three-way interaction of these variables. Trial number will also be included as a fixed effect. If the interaction term turns out to not be significant, we remove it and re-run the model with all the two-way interactions included. We further exclude any interaction terms which turn out to be non-significant.

Success_Preswitch = age*switch type (IDS/EDS)*relevant dimension in postswitch (cup/substrate) + trial number + (1|ID)

q20.value: We will z-transform age before entering it into the models.

q21.value: We will use the standard p < .05 criterion for determining if one of the fixed effects has a significant effect on the DV.

q22.value: Participants will not be included in the analysis of the pre-switch data if children terminate the testing on request (i.e., they do not reach the learning criterion or the maximum number of trials); similarly, participants will be excluded from the analysis of the postswitch phase if they terminate the postswitch phase on request.

q24.value:
For the exploratory analysis, we plan to explore children’s ability to articulate the rule for locating the sticker. They will be asked “Can you tell me how you found the sticker?” at the point of completion of the post-switch phase (i.e., children who did not reach the postswitch phase will not be asked, as it is assumed that these children did not learn the rule in the preswitch phase). 
This will be followed by a structured set of questions to prompt a response:
“Can you tell me how you found the sticker?”
If no response, 
“If we played the game again, where would you look for the sticker?”
If no response, 
“What if we played again now, where might I hide the sticker?”

That is, we would expect to find an effect of relevant dimension (or its absence) for children in both the IDS and the EDS condition, thereby showing that children of these two conditions did not differ in any meaningful way other than switch type.


Postswitch:
For the postswitch analysis, we will use age as a covariate, relevant dimension in the postswitch phase (cup/substrate) and switch type (IDS/EDS) as independent variables, as well as a three-way interaction of these variables. Trial number will also be included as a fixed effect. If the interaction term turns out to not be significant, we remove it and re-run the model with all the two-way interactions included. We further exclude any interaction terms which turn out to be non-significant.

Success_Preswitch = age*switch type (IDS/EDS)*relevant dimension in postswitch (cup/substrate) + trial number + (1|ID)

attributes.title: Dry needling for Subacromial Pain Syndrome: A Systematic Review and Metanalysis

q1.value: Dry needling for Subacromial Pain Syndrome: A Systematic Review and Metanalysis

q3.value:
Shoulder pain is a significant health problem presenting a prevalence of 25% in the
general population and the most prevalent diagnosis is subacromial pain syndrome. 

Also, shoulder pain cause a substantial annual cost in primary health care.  Therapeutic exercise probably exhibits the highest level of evidence for the treatment of shoulder pain conditions. Dry needling interventions have been used to treat musculoskeletal pain, and has shown to be effective for the treatment for neck and shoulder disorders. 

However, there is not any systematic review or meta-analysis has investigated the effects of dry needling in the subacromial pain syndrome.

q4.value: The treatment realized by dry needling alone or as adjunct with other interventions is more effective that other interventions, control or placebo for subacromial pain syndrome.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Systematic review and meta-analysis  that included randomized clinical trial or crossover randomized clinical trial that investigated the effects of dry needling alone or adjunct with other interventions and compared with a control group.

PICO question:
- Population: Shoulder pain OR Subacromial Pain Syndrome
Intervention: dry needling
- Comparison: sham OR placebo OR control OR intervention
- Outcome: pain OR disability OR function

Intervention: Dry needling (TrP-DN) is defined as a "skilled intervention using a thin filiform needle to penetrate the skin that stimulates Trigger Points, muscles, and connective tissue for the management of musculoskeletal disorders". The intervention could be realized alone or in combination with other therapies. 

Comparator group: Any control group is permited (E.g., sham or placebo, medication dry needling, laser therapy, exercise therapy)

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We included randomized clinical trial or crossover randomized clinical trial that investigated the effects of dry needling alone or adjunct with other interventions and compared with a control group.

The following databases were searched in PubMed, Cochrane Library, CINAHL, PEDro, Scopus and Web of Sciences. Clinical trials that had been in Spanish or English. Any restrictions in dates frame.

Anticipated or actual start date: 15/01/2020
Anticipated completion date: 15/04/2020

q13.value:
To be eligible, they had to fulfill the following criteria: (1) unilateral non-traumatic shoulder pain, (2) shoulder pain from at least 3 month, (3) diagnosed by positive common tests, (4) an acceptable comparator with another intervention, sham intervention, placebo or control and (5) any variable that studied changes in pain intensity (e.g., pain intensity measured as visual analogue scale or numeric rating scale) or disability

The exclusion criteria were (1) pain consequence of neurological disorders (e.g., hemiplegia) (2) acupuncture realized in traditional points of Chinese Medicine.

question.value:
- Pain intensity: any outcome to measure the pain intensity (e.g., visual analogue scale, numeric rating scale...). The data is extracted in different follow-ups
- Disability: any outcome to measure the disability or function of the patients (e.g., SPADI, DASH...). The data is extracted in different follow-ups
- Range of motion of the shoulder: any outcome to measure the range of motion of the shoulder (flexion, abduction, adduction, internal/external rotation...). The data is extracted in different follow-ups.

The data of the articles included will be used to realize a quantitative analysis. 

The mean diference (MD) between groups will be converted to standardized means difference (SMD), with a 95% confidence interval (CI). A random-effects model was used to determine the overall effect size: in SMD an effect size of 0.8 or greater was considered large, between 0.5 to 0.8 as moderate and between 0.2 to 0.5 as small, and p-values less than 0.05 were considered statistically significant. 

The heterogeneity of the studies will be assessed using the I² statistic. The Cochrane group has established the following interpretation of the I² statistic: 0-30% may not be relevant 0–30% may not be relevant; 30–60% presents moderate heterogeneity, and greater than 60% may represent substantial heterogeneity. 

The asymmetry was evaluated using a funnel plot in those analyses formed by at least five studies, which indicates the possible risk of publication of small studies with negative results. Studies were analyzed using the Review Manager 5.3 statistical software

Interventions were categorized in groups according to the follow up. We realized subgroups depending on the follow up

q25.value: Risk of bias and methodological quality were assessed by two authors. Randomized controlled clinical trials were evaluated with the Cochrane Collaboration tool for assessing the risk of bias. Additionally, the PEDro scale score was used to assess the methodological quality of the included studies. A score greater than or equal to 5 is considered to have high methodological quality

attributes.title: Effectiveness of percutaneos electrolysis for musculoskeletal pain: a systematic review and meta-analysis

q1.value: Effectiveness of percutaneos electrolysis for musculoskeletal pain: a systematic review and meta-analysis

q3.value:
Musculoskeletal pain occasion a large economic expenditure and a loss in quality of life and difficulty the daily activities, in Europe the incidence of chronic musculoskeletal pain around 19%.  Musculoskeletal pain includes many diagnoses, it could be led by unknown reasons or by specific structure disorders or pathologies.  Exercise and physical therapy have been recommended for the management of musculoskeletal pain. 

Percutaneous electrolysis (PE) consists of the application of a galvanic current through a needle in a targeted tissue, usually the tendon, muscle or other soft tissues. PE produces two main effects, a mechanical effect resulting from the insertion of the needle and the biological effect derived from the application of galvanic current, these effects cause a micro-trauma that generate a controlled inflammation promote de tissue regeneration and restoring the homeostasis. Due to the characteristics of the intervention, PE is often realized ultrasound-guided.  

Some series of case studies suggest that the percutaneous electrolysis added to an exercise program is effective for the treatment of different musculoskeletal disorders. In the last years, the number of controlled clinical trials in this area has increased, but there is not any review of this topic in the literature

q4.value: PE alone or as an adjunct with other interventions is effective on pain and related-disability in individuals with musculoskeletal pain disorders

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
We realized a systematic review and meta-analysis. 

The following databases were searched in PubMed, Cochrane Library, CINAHL, PEDro, Scopus and Web of Sciences. Clinical trials that had been in Spanish or English. Any restrictions in dates frame.

The question may be defined using PICO question:
- Population: Musculoskeletal pain
- Intervention: percutaneous electrolysis OR ultrasound-guided percutaneous electrolysis OR needle percutaneous electrolysis OR intratissue percutaneous electrolysis OR ultrasound guided galvanic electrolysis
- Comparison: sham OR placebo OR control OR intervention
- Outcome: pain OR disability OR function

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

question.value: The following data were extracted from the included studies: (1) bibliographic details: authors and year of publication; (2) demographics: number of participants, age and gender; (3) clinical information: musculoskeletal disorder diagnosis, disease duration, clinical pain intensity, intervention characteristics and outcome measures (e.g., visual analog scale [VAS], numeric rating scale [NRS], disability).

q13.value: We analyzed all studies that we can include and provide sufficient data to meta-analyze

question.value:
- Pain intensity: any outcome to measure the pain intensity (e.g., visual analogue scale, numeric rating scale, McGuill Pain...)
- Disability: any outcome to measure the disability or function of the patients (e.g., Oswestry Disability Index, Neck Disability Index, WOMAC...).

The data of the articles included will be used to realize a quantitative analysis. The mean diference (MD) between groups will be converted to standardized means difference (SMD), with a 95% confidence interval (CI). A random-effects model was used to determine the overall effect size: in SMD an effect size of 0.8 or greater was considered large, between 0.5 to 0.8 as moderate and between 0.2 to 0.5 as small, and p-values less than 0.05 were considered statistically significant. The heterogeneity of the studies will be assessed using the I² statistic. The Cochrane group has established the following interpretation of the I² statistic: 0-30% may not be relevant 0–30% may not be relevant; 30–60% presents moderate heterogeneity, and greater than 60% may represent substantial heterogeneity. The asymmetry was evaluated using a funnel plot in those analyses formed by at least five studies, which indicates the possible risk of publication of small studies with negative results. Studies were analyzed using the Review Manager 5.3 statistical software

Interventions were categorized in groups according to the follow up. We realized subgroups depending on the follow up: short, med and long-term.

q25.value: Risk of bias and methodological quality were assessed by two authors. Randomized controlled clinical trials were evaluated with the Cochrane Collaboration tool for assessing the risk of bias. Additionally, the PEDro scale score was used to assess the methodological quality of the included studies. A score greater than or equal to 5 is considered to have high methodological quality

q1.value: Replication: Reconstruction of Automobile Destruction: An Example of the Interaction Between Language and Memory

q2.value: Eliška Letová, Marek A. Vranka, Klára Milfaitová, Karolína Borská, David Jakes

q3.value:
We will replicate study: Reconstruction of Automobile Destruction: An Example of the Interaction Between Language and Memory to see if there will be a described effect of language on memory and estimation in a language other than English, namely Czech.
Probands will be gradually released records of 7 car accidents of several cars ranging from 5 to 30 seconds. Afterwards, probands receive questionnaires on five issues related to this accident. All questionnaires will ask how quickly proband thinks that the cars went when a car crash occurred. The remaining questions will act as distractors to distract attention from the pivotal question.
This question about speed will vary with which word describes a car accident.

q4.value:
Our hypothes is non-directional. 
We assume that there will be a significant difference between the speed estimates of cars, which would indicate that the chosen word has an effect on speed estimation.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Probands do not know which question is the key questionnaire and will always answer all questions.

question.value:
45 probands receive a random questionnaire and are divided into five groups. These groups differ according to the words that will be used in the key question - How fast the cars went when: do sebe napálila/ do sebe narazila/ do sebe vletěla/ se setkala/ do sebe najela. 
It is a between subject design.

q9.value: For each proband we roll a dice and assign a questionnaire according to the number on the dice. If we hit number 6, we throw again.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Probands will be gradually released records of 7 car accidents of several cars ranging from 5 to 30 seconds. Afterwards, probands receive questionnaires on five issues related to this accident. All questionnaires will ask how quickly proband thinks that the cars went when a car crash occurred. The remaining questions will act as distractors to distract attention from the pivotal question while verifying whether the proband was watching the video.

q14.value: We want to follow the original study

question.value: Which word do we use in the key question - How fast did the cars go when ...
estimated speed of cars - their average

The averages are compared using ANOVA
ANOVA

attributes.title: Scoping Review Protocol: Evidence-Based Quality Improvement as an Implementation Strategy for Evidence-Based Practices

q1.value: Scoping Review Protocol: Evidence-Based Quality Improvement as an Implementation Strategy for Evidence-Based Practices

q2.value: Susanne Hempel, Maria Bolshakova, Barbara Turner, Danielle Rose, Jennifer Dinalo, Aneesa Motala, Chase Clemesha, Drizelle Baluyot, Susan Stockdale

q3.value: The purpose of this scoping review of the literature is to characterize Evidence-Based Quality Improvement (EBQI) approaches that have been used to implement evidence-based practices, to identify any available methods or instruments to assess fidelity to the EBQI implementation strategy (i.e., the extent to which the implementation strategy is used as intended), and to document evidence of effectiveness of EBQI strategies for promoting uptake of evidence-based practices.

q4.value:
The scoping review will be guided by the following review questions:
•	KQ1: How is EBQI defined?
	KQ1a: What are the components of EBQI?
•	KQ2: How is evidence used to inform evidence-informed quality improvement initiatives 
        (QIIs)?
	KQ2a: How is evidence defined in these QIIs?
•	KQ3: Are there published fidelity measures that are applicable to EBQI?
•	KQ4: What is the effectiveness of EBQI to promote uptake of evidence-based practices?

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Scoping review

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: The scoping review is based on published literature and other documents in the public domain.

question.value:
Search strategy
The literature searches will be tailored to the key questions.
Regarding KQ1, a search for EBQI using the exact terms (either abbreviated or the exact words) will be employed. This search strategy aims to identify all publications that explicitly refer to EBQI. The search strategy for the database PubMed is documented in the appendix.
Regarding KQ2, a broader search strategy will identify quality improvement intervention (QII) evaluations. The search strategy assumes that there is little consensus on terminology. Some EBQI publications will not describe their work as EBQI even when authors have explicitly used an evidence-based strategy for quality improvement. In addition, although authors may describe an EBQI approach in the full text article of the study, the title, abstract, or keyword of the publication may not reference EBQI, i.e., the elements that are searchable in research databases such as PubMed will not mention EBQI. For this reason, we are using two independent search strategies to identify relevant publications for KQ1 and KQ2. To answer KQ2, we will sample the QII literature to identify evaluations of initiatives that meet basic eligibility criteria. The search will be limited to three years in order to allow the use of an unselected sample of studies within the given resources of the project. The preliminary search strategy for one database is documented in the appendix. 
Regarding KQ3, we will conduct a search for fidelity measures that may have been published in the scientific literature or that are available in the public domain. The draft search strategy is documented in the appendix.
Regarding KQ4, we will use EBQI studies meeting inclusion criteria for KQ1 and we will augment the sample with KQ2 studies that two independent literature reviewers deem compatible with EBQI.

Sources
We will search research databases and grey literature for the scoping review. To identify publications relevant to KQ1, KQ2, or KQ3, we will search the research databases PubMed (biomedical literature), CINAHL (nursing and allied health profession literature), and SCOPUS (social sciences). In addition, we will mine the references of included publications and confer with content experts. To identify fidelity measures, we will also search https://dissemination-implementation.org/, an interactive webtool for implementation and dissemination models and tools. KQ4 will use evaluation studies meeting inclusion criteria for KQ1 and KQ2.

Eligibility criteria
The eligibility criteria are organized in a SPIOS (study design, participants, intervention, outcome, setting) framework where applicable.
KQ1: EBQI sample
•	Citations using the term “evidence-based quality improvement” or “evidence based quality improvement” in the title, abstract, and keyword of the publication will be eligible for inclusion regardless of the study design and publication year, participants, intervention, outcome, or setting. We will accept the authors’ definition of EBQI.
KQ2: Additional QI sample
•	Study design and publication type
o	Eligible publications have to report on the results of an intervention and have to have been published in the last three years, i.e., when the term EBQI has been used more frequently in publications.2-5,8,10-15,17,18,20,22,25-27,34,36,42 Empirical studies may use concurrent (e.g., randomized controlled trials, clinical trials) or historic comparators (pre-post studies, organizational case series, time series). 
o	We will retain relevant systematic reviews for reference-mining.
•	Participants
o	Publications have to address healthcare professionals working on quality improvement in healthcare delivery organizations to be eligible.
•	Intervention 
o	Publications addressing quality improvement in healthcare delivery organizations and learning health systems will be eligible. Quality improvement is defined as a structural change in how healthcare is delivered. Studies need to refer to a literature or evidence review in the development of the QII by the healthcare delivery organization (evidence can be defined as published research evidence as well as locally generated data). In addition, studies need to report on continued use of evidence during the initiative after selecting the intervention or implementation strategy, e.g., using data to evaluate the effects of the QII (Plan-Do-Study-Act [PDSA] cycles, statistical process control).
•	Outcome
o	Empirical studies reporting on the effect of a QII will be eligible. Studies may report on structural measures (e.g., organizational changes, costs), process measures (e.g., performance measures such as number of tests ordered; utilization, unintended consequences), and outcomes (e.g., health outcomes, patient satisfaction, adverse events)
•	Setting
o	Studies in primary care will be eligible. Studies in secondary care facilities, hospitals, nursing homes, dentist facilities, and laboratories, or other facilities without direct contact to patients will be excluded. In addition, we will exclude studies in developing countries.
KQ3: Fidelity measures
•	Tools assessing fidelity will be eligible for inclusion. These tools need to assess the fidelity with which an intervention or implementation strategy was executed as intended. Tools may be designed to assess overall fidelity or fidelity to specific intervention or implementation strategy components. Existing tools will be included regardless of the format (e.g., website), study design and publication type and year, or clinical area. Tools are not limited to EBQI or quality improvement.
KQ4: Effectiveness sample
All studies reporting effectiveness results for evaluation of an EBQI initiative will be eligible for inclusion. In addition, two independent literature reviewers will assess studies included in KQ2 for compatibility with EBQI. 
•	Study design and publication type
o	KQ1 or KQ2 publications have to report on the results of an intervention to be eligible for KQ4. Empirical studies may use concurrent (e.g., randomized controlled trials, clinical trials) or historic comparators (pre-post studies, organizational case series, time series). 
•	Participants
o	KQ1 or KQ2 publications have to address healthcare professionals working on quality improvement in healthcare delivery organizations to be eligible.
•	Intervention 
o	KQ1 and KQ2 QII publications in healthcare delivery organizations and learning health systems will be eligible. Studies need to describe their approach as EBQI or refer to a literature or evidence review as part of the development as well as the evaluation of the initiative. 
•	Outcome
o	KQ1 and KQ2 empirical QII studies reporting on patient outcomes will be eligible.
•	Setting
o	KQ1 and KQ2 empirical evaluations of QI interventions in primary care will be eligible; studies in developing countries will be excluded.
Data abstraction
For all EBQI citations (KQ1) we will abstract the following:
•	Author, publication year, unique study identifier
•	Definition of EBQI or the first sentence where EBQI is mentioned
•	Other relevant concept associated with EBQI
•	Funded by the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA)
•	Reference to Lisa Rubenstein’s group (known EBQI researchers) 
•	Reference to any other EBQI publication in lieu of defining EBQI 
In addition, we will abstract EBQI components (KQ1a, KQ2). The data abstraction will use the draft components listed here together with the current working definition of the components:
•	Using evidence (data) to identify the target of the QI intervention
o	Citing a literature review as part of the process of identifying an issue or problem, or a description of local data demonstrating the issue
•	Iterative, interactive process for selecting the intervention and identifying evidence
o	Evidence of a back-and-forth discussion within the organization, interactive selection of the intervention
•	Reaching out to stakeholders in the organization, collaborative process
o	Engaging diverse organizational stakeholders; top-down/bottom-up approach
•	Evidence to identify effective interventions
o	Describes a literature review to identify effective interventions in the research literature (or find authoritative source that recommends specific interventions)
•	QI facilitation
o	May refer to an external facilitator, internal coordinator or learning collaborative; coaching and mentoring for quality improvement processes
•	Leadership / management involvement
o	Medical director, nurse leadership, primary care leadership, chief medical officer, nurse manager; some evidence of ongoing involvement, more than one-time approval or briefing at the end
•	Frontline personnel engagement 
o	Clinicians (physician, nurse practitioner, physician assistants), allied clinical staff (nurses, licensed vocational nurses, medical assistants), administrative staff (e.g., front desk, scheduling); engagement needs to start at selecting intervention, not just when change is decided
•	Use of evidence to determine success
o	Evaluation data of the intervention (feasibility, intervention adherence, effectiveness, performance measures; quantitative or qualitative data); this may include an iterative approach, PDSA cycles or collaborative learning sessions
•	Analytic support
o	Dedicated statistician, additional analyst beyond the clinical team; statistical support to analyze results of the intervention, analysis of multiple data sources, analysis of performance feedback, formative feedback analysis
•	Other (specify)
o	E.g., champion, VA demonstration site leader (manager of clinic), practice manager, regional experts, academic experts (e.g., homelessness content expert), adverse events, unintended consequences monitored?
•	Context
o	For context, we will also abstract study ID, topic area, type of outcome, definition of evidence, engagement (who is part of the initiative), named QI and implementation strategy
We expect that the descriptions will be further refined to allow reliable study characterization. The working definitions will be informed by the current empirical evidence, i.e., the included studies. Areas difficult to operationalize will be documented in detail to ensure transparency such as classifying the role of a project manager, the differentiation between administrative and clinical leadership, how ongoing involvement should be defined, whether use of evidence was iterative, and whether access to data may be more critical than analytic support. 
KQ2
For KQ2, we will abstract from the EBQI intervention evaluations and the broader QI sample how “evidence” was used according to the study authors. In addition, we will extract from the studies how “evidence” was defined (KQ2a). We will also abstract additional information for context:
•	Study ID
•	Topic area
•	Type of outcome
•	Definition of evidence
•	Engagement (who is part of the initiative)
•	Named QI and implementation strategy
KQ3
For KQ3 we will abstract for each included tool (e.g., https://www.pbis.org/resource/tips-fidelity-checklist):
•	Tool name
•	Developers
•	Publication year
•	Aim, purpose, and scope
•	Underlying model 
•	Description (e.g., number of items, answer mode)
•	Reliability information (e.g., rater agreement)
•	Validity information (e.g., evidence that the fidelity scale measures fidelity)
•	Link to tool (where available) or citation of publication about the tool
KQ4
For studies meeting inclusion criteria for KQ4 we will abstract the following variables:
•	Study ID
•	Study design
•	Setting
•	Participants
•	EBQI / implementation strategy
•	Intervention (clinical area, type, description)
•	Outcome and results (number of participants in the intervention group, number of participants in the control group, outcome type, exact measure, follow-up relative to the start of the intervention rollout, results in comparison to the control group [point estimate and measure of dispersion])

q14.value: We will document the presence and absence of information.

question.value: N/A

To answer KQ1 (How is EBQI defined?), all identified EBQI definitions will be documented. This collation of definitions will be based on publications explicitly using the term “EBQI” in the title or abstract of the publication. 
To answer KQ1a (What are the components of EBQI?), we will employ a 2-step process. First, we will document the components described in the EBQI sample, i.e., evaluations explicitly referencing EBQI. The evidence table will include a grid of components that will allow a clear overview of the relative frequency of components. The synthesis will follow the structure of the table. The component table will serve as an overarching EBQI framework. In a second step, the component analysis will be applied to a wider QII sample. The results of applying the component analysis to this sample will be documented in an evidence table and narrative synthesis. The summary aims to answer the questions regarding the components of EBQI described in EBQI-compatible studies.
The scoping review will outline how evidence is used to inform QIIs to address KQ2. This exploratory approach will abstract free text descriptions. The results will be documented in a evidence and component table (see above). A narrative synthesis will compare and contrast approaches and reference specific examples from the recent literature.
The scoping review will also analyze how “evidence” has been defined in existing EBQI and QII studies (KQ2a). The information will be documented in transparent component tables. The included studies will inform a categorization scheme of evidence types (e.g., published research studies, local data collected for the quality improvement initiative).	
All identified measures will be documented in an evidence table to answer KQ3. We will list the web address where possible to provide a useful resource.
The effects of EBQI (KQ4) will be documented in detail in an evidence table. The table will provide context to understand the study results.

In order to facilitate effectiveness comparisons across studies, we will compute effect sizes for all studies. Effect sizes such as standardized mean differences or relative risks are measure independent and easy to interpret. We will provide a summary estimate where appropriate. In addition, we will use meta-regressions and subgroup analyses to identify components that are systematically associated with the effectiveness of interventions.

Key questions 1-3 will be summarized in a narrative synthesis. For KQ4, we will provide a statistical summary estimate where appropriate. In addition, we will use meta-regressions and subgroup analyses to identify components that are systematically associated with the effectiveness of interventions.

q20.value: In order to facilitate effectiveness comparisons across studies, we will compute effect sizes for all studies. Effect sizes such as standardized mean differences or relative risks are measure independent and easy to interpret.

q21.value: The effect sizes will be documented together with the 95% confidence interval. We will interpret the direction of effects as well as the statistical significance of the effect.

q22.value: Where necessary we will conduct sensitivity analyses to determine the effect of outliers.

q23.value: Incomplete and missing data will be documented in the evidence table and highlighted in the text where appropriate.

attributes.title: Morality Threat and Perceptions of Cultural Celebration

q3.value: This research examines how the motivation to defend against threats to one’s moral character can bias estimates of acts of a target engaging with an out-group cultural product among White perceivers.

q4.value:
Study 1 Predicted Results

When reading about a White target taking from Black culture, White perceivers who experience threats to moral identity (vs. control) will:

a)	report increased perceptions of "cultural celebration" (and reduced evidentiary standards for such appraisals) 

b)	report reduced perceptions of cultural appropriation (and increased evidentiary standards for such appraisals)

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This study will use a 2 (Threat: Threat vs. Control) x 2 (Target Race) between-subjects design.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to conditions via a randomized embedded within the Qualtrics online software (qualtrics.com).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will recruit will recruit participants for this study using a nationally representative sample of self-reported White Americans via Amazon's Mechanical Turk (mturk.com) who are over 18, and reside in the United States. 

Participants will be asked to complete a race-honesty check at the end of the study to confirm their racial demographics.

q13.value: We will recruit will recruit 240 adults for this study who identify as White-American.

question.value: Morality Threat (Threat vs. No Threat)

Participants will complete a 4 -item measure of perceptions of cultural celebration (e.g. “This chef is celebrating/honoring/commemorating Black/White culture [tailored to target race,”) and perceptions of cultural appropriation (e.g. “This chef is appropriating/copying/taking from/ Black/White culture [tailored to target race], “,”)  Participants will respond to both measures on a 7-point Likert-type scale from 1 = Strongly Disagree ; 7 = Strongly Agree)

Participants will also complete a measure of evidentiary standards, which will assess standards for the source community (e.g. “Please indicate what percentage of (source group) White-Americans/Black-Americans would be harmed culturally, socially or economically by this scenario for you to consider this to be an act of cultural appropriation?”) and cultural celebration (“Please indicate what percentage of (source group) White-Americans/Black-Americans would benefit culturally, socially or economically by this scenario for you to consider this to be an act of cultural celebration?).

Perceptions of Appropriation (1 = Strongly Disagree to 7 =Strongly Agree; Mosley & Biernat, in review, JPSP): 
1.	This person is appropriating Black/White culture.
2.	This person is copying Black/White culture.
3.	This person is taking from Black/White culture.
4.	This person is displaying an element of culture that is not their own.
A mean index of appropriation will be created, with higher scores indicating greater perceptions of appropriation. 


Perceptions of Celebration (1 = Strongly Disagree to 7 =Strongly Agree) This person is appropriating Black/White culture.
1.	This person is celebrating Black/White culture.
2.	This person is appreciating Black/White culture.
3.	This person is honoring Black/White culture.
4.	This person is commemorating Black/White culture.

A mean index of celebration will be created, with higher scores indicating greater perceptions of celebration. 


Evidentiary Standards (0-10%, 10-25%, 25-40%, 40-60%, 60-75%, 75-90%, and 90-100%; Miron, Branscombe, & Biernat, 2010)

•	“Please indicate what percentage of (source group) White-Americans/Black-Americans would be harmed culturally, socially or economically by this scenario for you to consider this to be an act of cultural appropriation?” 

•	“Please indicate what percentage of (source group) White-Americans/Black-Americans would benefit culturally, socially or economically by this scenario for you to consider this to be an act of cultural celebration?”
Scores on dependent measures will be submitted to a 2 (Threat: High Threat vs. No Threat) X 2 (Target Race:White Target vs. Black Target) Analysis of Variance.

registration_responses.q3: This research examines how the motivation to defend against threats to one’s moral character can bias estimates of acts of a target engaging with an out-group cultural product among White perceivers.
registration_responses.q4:
Study 1 Predicted Results

When reading about a White target taking from Black culture, White perceivers who experience threats to moral identity (vs. control) will:

a)	report increased perceptions of "cultural celebration" (and reduced evidentiary standards for such appraisals) 

b)	report reduced perceptions of cultural appropriation (and increased evidentiary standards for such appraisals)
